page.title: 03River Nar
page.content:
The river Nar is a tributary of the Great Ouse. It has a local nickname - the New World. Quite a few people go "rough" camping and fishing there, as it is a quiet and secluded area.
A pupil writes: I went camping with my brother. We got chased by a bull. Later we went into an orchard and took some apples. We had baked apples for tea.
The river is quite narrow (3-5m wide) and has dike banks to stop it flooding, or connecting with the farm drainage ditches. There are also flood gates which can be manually controlled if necessary.
The river is a haven for birds and wildlife and is flanked by farm fields, mainly growing wheat.
